publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: ninety, O venerable ones, Pāt. (lit. making someone fall)-dharmas have been recited by me. Here I as before. || || O venerable ones, now these four Pratid. (lit. to be reported)-dharmas
come to the recitation of Prātimokṣasūtra each half month. || Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. Then,
it was the time of hunger. A lot of honor and reverence turned to the nun Utpalavarṇā. She obtained much food.
Der Nonne Utpalavarṇā wandte sich viel Verehrung [und] Ehrerbietung zu [d.h. wurde viel Verehrung und Ehrerbietung zuteil].
Much reverence and obeisance [was] turned towards the nun Utpalavarṇā [i.e. was bestowed upon her].
She gave it as food to the monks. The third day came to her, (that) she remained without eating. Thereafter, the attack of weakness seized her. She was still walking and fell on the street.
Darauf ergriff sie [scil. die Nonne Utpalavarṇā] ein Schwächeanfall.
Thereupon, she [i.e. the nun Utpalavarṇā] was seized by a dizzy spell.
A certain merchant saw her. Suddenly he returned (to his home) and informed his wife. Thereafter, she came, carried her and prepared food for her. Buddha
Darauf kam sie, hob sie auf [wtl. richtete sie auf], führte sie in [ihre] Behausung [und] bereitete(?) ihr Essen.
Thereupon she came, lifted her up, led her into [her] home [and] prepared(?) food for her.
heard and blamed. || If a monk, not being sick, seizes hard food and soft food by his own hand from an unrelated nun who enters into one house for alms,

Which monk not being ill goes into the inside of a house for alms-begging, and takes hard and soft food with his own hand from an unrelated nun, that monk has to confess to the monks: 'In a condemnable matter, o honourable ones, I have trespassed [lit. crossed the place].'
it should be reported to other monks by this monk. 'O venerable ones, I have violated a point by something to be blamed.
What is not suitable should be announced. I announce this point. This is a rule to be reported.' || || Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. A certain patron

Ein Gabenherr lud die Mönche und Nonnen zum Essen ein. Darauf belehrte Sthūlanandā den Gabenherren: 'Jener ist ein Āraṇyaka, gib ihm zuerst! Doch jene sind Āgamadharas; jener aber ist ein Ābhidhārmika; jener ein Vinayadhara(?).' Der Gabenherr ärgerte sich darüber. 'Befiehl du, wir [aber] sollen ruhig bleiben [wtl. sitzen]'.

A donator invited the monks and nuns to a meal. Thereupon Sthūlanandā instructed the donator: 'That one is an Āraṇyaka, give [food] to him first! But those are Āgamadharas; that one, however, is an Ābhidhārmika; that one a Vinayadhara(?).' The donator was irritated by this. 'You, command [us], [but] we shall sit still'.
invited the monks and the nuns to the meal. Thereafter, Sthūlanandā informed the patron: 'The one is there is āraṇyaka. Give him at first.
Then, these are āgamadharas. He is ābhidhārmika. He is vinayadhara.' Therefore, the patron got angry. 'Order, you.
Because of that the benefactor was upset, [and said], 'You order! We will remain quiet.'
We will sit silently.' Buddha heard and blamed. || Many monks should be invited to the meal in several different houses, if there is a nun would be standing,

If monks were invited into dwellings to eat on the way (?), and a nun were standing there giving instructions, 'Give rice here!', 'Give soup here!', 'Give more here!', [then] this nun should be [addressed] by the monks like this …
who indicates: 'Give rice here, give broth here, give here more.' The nun should be said in this way by the monks.

p.note: A parallel text is found in .
According to 74, "in a very good state of preservation. Written in medium sized ductus of the same hand" as .

a1 ninety, O venerable ones, Pāt. (lit. making someone fall)-dharmas have been recited by me. Here I as before. || || O venerable ones, now these four Pratid. (lit. to be reported)-dharmas a2 come to the recitation of Prātimokṣasūtra each half month. || Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. Then, a3 it was the time of hunger. A lot of honor and reverence turned to the nun Utpalavarṇā. She obtained much food. a4 She gave it as food to the monks. The third day came to her, (that) she remained without eating. Thereafter, the attack of weakness seized her. She was still walking and fell on the street. a5 A certain merchant saw her. Suddenly he returned (to his home) and informed his wife. Thereafter, she came, carried her and prepared food for her. Buddha a6 heard and blamed. || If a monk, not being sick, seizes hard food and soft food by his own hand from an unrelated nun who enters into one house for alms, b1 it should be reported to other monks by this monk. 'O venerable ones, I have violated a point by something to be blamed. b2 What is not suitable should be announced. I announce this point. This is a rule to be reported.' || || Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. A certain patron b3 invited the monks and the nuns to the meal. Thereafter, Sthūlanandā informed the patron: 'The one is there is āraṇyaka. Give him at first. b4 Then, these are āgamadharas. He is ābhidhārmika. He is vinayadhara.' Therefore, the patron got angry. 'Order, you. b5 We will sit silently.' Buddha heard and blamed. || Many monks should be invited to the meal in several different houses, if there is a nun would be standing, b6 who indicates: 'Give rice here, give broth here, give here more.' The nun should be said in this way by the monks.

a1 śaulassoñcä ñumka • īpäṣṣeñcana pelaiknenta • omte ñäś mäkte nauṣ || || cai no ś(aula)ssoñcä śtw(ā)ra wrantsai aksaṣṣäl(yana pe-) a2 -laiknenta artsa ywarca meñ prātimokṣäṣṣepi sutarntse akṣalñene ecce känmaskeṃ • || pañ(ä)kte śrāvastine mäskīträ • ot no k(e)- a3 -statse preke ṣai • uppalavarṇañ aśiyantse • yarke peti māka sporttīträ • māka śwatsanma kälpāṣṣi • tu ṣamā- a4 -nets päst aiṣṣi śwātsi • tāy no trite kauṃ ṣai • eśuwacca mäskīträ • tumeṃ leswi eṅksante-ne|eṅsanta-ne • yaka ynemane nauntaine klāya • a5 käryorttau ksa lyakā-ne • istak|ista= klautka • śnoy ākṣa • tumeṃ sā_u śem kauc ersate-ne • oskai wayāte-ne • śwātsi wäṅkṣāte-ne • pañäkte a6 klyauṣa nāksate || mäksu no ṣamāne mā alāṣmo eneṅka osne piṃtwātäśc ynemane • aletsai aśiyaimeṃ • ṣañ ṣarsa trās(k)a- b1 -lye • tsāltalye eñcīträ • cau|ce_u ṣamānentsa • ṣamānents āksaṣälle • nakṣalyesa śaulassoñc īke kätkau nesau • mā ayāto a- b2 -ksaṣṣälye • cau|cew īke aksaskau • se pelaikne wrantsai aksaṣṣälle • || || pañäkte śrāvastine mäskīträ • tanāpate ksa ṣamā- b3 -neṃ aśiyana ṣpä śwātsiś kakāte • tumeṃ sthulanānda cau|ce_u tanāpateṃ śarsäṣṣi • samp arāññe ste cwim nauṣ pete • b4 caim no agamadhari skente • sam no abhidharmike ste • sam winasāre • tusa tanāpate kraṣiyate • twe pitka wes ā- b5 -m lamam • pañäkte klyauṣa nāksate || ṣamāni no masār ostuwaiwentane kakākaṣ tākoṃ śwātsiśco • omte kwri|kr_ui aśiya ṣär(ps)e- b6 -maneñña stmausa tākoy • tane klu pete • tane smaññe pete • tane (ṣpa)k«†ä» pete • sāw a(śiya) ṣamānent(s) mäntrākka tākoy e –
According to [[Broomhead I]]: 74, "in a very good state of preservation. Written in medium sized ductus of the same hand" as [[IOL Toch 247]].
A parallel text is found in [[IOL Toch 137]].

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a6-b1 Which monk not being ill goes into the inside of a house for alms-begging, and takes hard and soft food with his own hand from an unrelated nun, that monk has to confess to the monks: 'In a condemnable matter, o honourable ones, I have trespassed [lit. crossed the place].' 693
b4-5 Because of that the benefactor was upset, [and said], 'You order! We will remain quiet.' 299
b5-6 If monks were invited into dwellings to eat on the way (?), and a nun were standing there giving instructions, 'Give rice here!', 'Give soup here!', 'Give more here!', [then] this nun should be [addressed] by the monks like this … 348


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Der Nonne Utpalavarṇā wandte sich viel Verehrung [und] Ehrerbietung zu [d.h. wurde viel Verehrung und Ehrerbietung zuteil]. 78, 119, 281
a4 Darauf ergriff sie [scil. die Nonne Utpalavarṇā] ein Schwächeanfall. 74
a5 Darauf kam sie, hob sie auf [wtl. richtete sie auf], führte sie in [ihre] Behausung [und] bereitete(?) ihr Essen. 328-9, fn. 5, 387
b2-5 Ein Gabenherr lud die Mönche und Nonnen zum Essen ein. Darauf belehrte Sthūlanandā den Gabenherren: 'Jener ist ein Āraṇyaka, gib ihm zuerst! Doch jene sind Āgamadharas; jener aber ist ein Ābhidhārmika; jener ein Vinayadhara(?).' Der Gabenherr ärgerte sich darüber. 'Befiehl du, wir [aber] sollen ruhig bleiben [wtl. sitzen]'. 167, 381


Translation according to [[Broomhead I]]: 75-76:

a1 "Ye worthy ones the ninety pātayantika dharmāḥ have been pronounced by me [cf. [[IOL Toch 247]]: b6 weweñuwa ñässa]. I there as before [sic! - TI]. Ye worthy ones, these four pratideśanīyā dharmaḥ now

a2 appear in the recital of the Prātimokṣasūtra every half month." Buddha was staying in Śrāvasti. At that time

a3 then there was a famine (a time of famine). People showed great honour and reverence to the nun Utpalavarṇā. Repeatedly she received much food,

a4 which (= that) [however] she gave away to the monks for food. Now it was the third day that she had not eaten. Thereupon she was seized by lassitude however when walking in the street she fell.

a5 A [certain] merchant saw her. Immediately he turned back [and] informed his wife. The latter forthwith came [out], lifted her up, lead [sic! - TI] her into her house [and] weṃṅkṣāte her food.

a6 Buddha heard [and] rebuked [this]. "Whichever monk, not [being] sick, takes, from a strange nun, who has entered an inner room in order to get alms, hard [and]

b1 soft food, this monk shall announce it to the monks. "Ye worthy ones, with regard to something culpable I have trespassed (the place)." The impropriety must

b2 be proclaimed. I announce this point. That is a pratideśanīya dharma." Buddha was staying in Śrāvasti.

b3 A contributor (dānapati) invited the monks and nuns in to eat. Thereupon Sthūlanandā instructed the contributor. "That one is an Āraṇyaka. Give him to eat first.

b4 But those are Āgamadharas. That one however is an Ābhidhārmika. That one [is] a winasāre. The contributor became vexed [and said]. "You order, we shall sit quiet."

b5 Buddha heard [of this] [and] reprimanded [it]. "Should monks on a journey be invited into dwellings, if there be

b6 any pointing nun there [saying] "Give here rice, give here soup, give more here!" This (f.) ... it should be just so for the monks."


[[Broomhead I]]: 76-77 contains further notes on text and translation.


TEKST OGI nog niet vergeleken

div.p: Translation according to <citedRange>75-76</citedRange></bibl>: </p><p>a1 "Ye worthy ones the ninety pātayantika dharmāḥ have been pronounced by me [cf. <ref type="ms" target="txt:m-ioltoch247"/>: b6 <hi>weweñuwa ñässa</hi>]. I there as before [sic! - TI]. Ye worthy ones, these four pratideśanīyā dharmaḥ now </p><p>a2 appear in the recital of the Prātimokṣasūtra every half month." Buddha was staying in Śrāvasti. At that time </p><p>a3 then there was a famine (a time of famine). People showed great honour and reverence to the nun Utpalavarṇā. Repeatedly she received much food, </p><p>a4 which (= that) [however] she gave away to the monks for food. Now it was the third day that she had not eaten. Thereupon she was seized by lassitude however when walking in the street she fell. </p><p>a5 A [certain] merchant saw her. Immediately he turned back [and] informed his wife. The latter forthwith came [out], lifted her up, lead [sic! - TI] her into her house [and] weṃṅkṣāte her food. </p><p>a6 Buddha heard [and] rebuked [this]. "Whichever monk, not [being] sick, takes, from a strange nun, who has entered an inner room in order to get alms, hard [and] </p><p>b1 soft food, this monk shall announce it to the monks. "Ye worthy ones, with regard to something culpable I have trespassed (the place)." The impropriety must </p><p>b2 be proclaimed. I announce this point. That is a pratideśanīya dharma." Buddha was staying in Śrāvasti. </p><p>b3 A contributor (dānapati) invited the monks and nuns in to eat. Thereupon Sthūlanandā instructed the contributor. "That one is an Āraṇyaka. Give him to eat first. </p><p>b4 But those are Āgamadharas. That one however is an Ābhidhārmika. That one [is] a winasāre. The contributor became vexed [and said]. "You order, we shall sit quiet." </p><p>b5 Buddha heard [of this] [and] reprimanded [it]. "Should monks on a journey be invited into dwellings, if there be </p><p>b6 any pointing nun there [saying] "Give here rice, give here soup, give more here!" This (f.) ... it should be just so for the monks." </p><p><bibl><title corresp="ref:broomhead1962"/><citedRange>76-77</citedRange></bibl> contains further notes on text and translation.</p><p>TEKST OGI nog niet vergeleken</p></project_comment>
